title: How can we use 'whose' here, 'Whose book is this' or 'Whose is this book'? - Quora

response.answer_text: Both of those sentences are valid options. “Whose book in this” sounds a bit less awkward. You’ve A2A’d me a half-dozen similar questions. Rather than answer each individually, might I point you toward an online resource? The Purdue OWL: Grammar The Purdue OWL site has explanations of different grammar concepts, complete with examples. It also contains resources for MLA citation format, writing in specific fields (literary criticism, technical writing, etc.), and other handy pages. The link I’ve included will take you directly to the grammar page.

I agree that Whose book is this is standard everyday English. But consider the poem that begins Whose woods these are I think I know….. So…. Whose book this is I think I know… He is not here right now, and so I think that I will have a look Inside his favorite little book To see if something deep inside Is something that he wants to hide. With profound apologies to Robert Frost.

The general formula is that when such expressions as WHOSE, HOW MANY, WHICH are used as question words, the noun they go with stays with them. HOW MANY PENCILS DO YOU WANT? (HOW MANY MUST STAY WITH PENCILS.) In the same way, WHOSE BOOK IS THIS?
